characters: EXT HILL ABOVE THE ENGLISH CAMP- NIGHT
EXT HILL ABOVE THE ENGLISH CAMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Painted images of the Elizabethan age -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A world divided by religious hatred. The new Protestant faith is spreading. Bodies burned on a pyre - men writhing under torture - a momentary half-recognisable face, gaunt and staring - FATHER ROBERT RESTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most powerful ruler in Christendom, Philip of Spain, has sworn to return all Europe to the Catholic faith. Images of rival monarchs Philip and Elizabeth in court paintings: stiff, formal, imperious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only England stands in his way: a weak impoverished nation ruled by a woman. Finally images of God in judgement, as if speaking to his chosen servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philip prepares to obey the will 2             of his God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bn ascetic-looking man dressed in black kneels in a small plain chapel, in virtual darkness. PHILIP II, King of Spa bows his head low, abasing himself before his God.

dialogues.speaker: S/I CAPTION
dialogues.text: scorial Palace, Spain, 1585. Now, slowly, he raises his head. His eyes open, and we se there the glow of a new certainty. God has spoken to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (I hear. I obey. My Lord and my 1 God.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 Philip walks rapidly down a long corridor that opens out into a broader hallway, moving from the darkness of the chapel into ever brighter light and more visible glory. O his face the far shining gaze of a man who now knows his mission. Silent servants press themselves to the walls as he goes by. Through the hallway to a grand salon. COURTIE fall silent and bow as he passes. So into the grandest salon of all, where his magnificent court is gathered; among them his 12-year-old daughter, the INFANTA. As he enters, all kneel. His eyes scan his ministers and courtiers, all kneeling, heads bowed before him. His gaze falls on one who wears t plain black robes of a Jesuit priest: Robert Reston, the face we glimpsed in the opening montage. He speaks to all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (God has made his will known to me. The time for our great enterprise has come.) The Jesuit looks up and his eyes too show a powerful but disciplined satisfaction. He murmurs softly to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last. Cathedral bells ring out. The cheers of a crowd are heard through the open windows. The king passes out onto the salon's first-floor balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 Hot sunlight. Philip stands gazing across the plaza at th great cathedral on the far side, as the bells ring out an the CROWD in the plaza below wave their hats and cheer. T Infanta is by his side. His MINISTERS cluster behind him. Lining the crowd on either side of the plaza stand column of ARMED SOLDIERS: a formidable reminder of the king's power. Philip does nothing, but his presence intoxicates the crowd. As their cries swell, wave upon wave, the king's eyes glow and he breathes in deeply, feeding on his people's adoration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 A ripple of light on the water. A blur of approaching colour. May 1 Blue Draft--p.3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROYAL BARGE is gliding towards us, slowly taking shap its hull gaily painted, its canopy adorned with colourful fabrics, its banks of oars rising and falling, casting bright shards of shining water in the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: P
dialogues.text: eople passing on the river bank point and wave, smiling, cheering. They see the Queen now. They call out. Two young men walking arm-in-arm stare more intently than any; but they do not cheer or wave. There's something chilling in the way they track the distant figure of the Queen. They are BABINGTON and SAVAGE. Over this an insistent voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you go among the people, majesty? I tell you plainly, you will be murdered! Every Catholic in England is a potential assassin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 An agitated group is gathered in this room where the business of state is transacted. We catch glimpses of the Queen in their midst, preparing to leave, as her minister try to persuade her of the seriousness of the situation: SIR CHRISTOPHER HATTON, 30s, an ambitious courtier; LORD HOWARD, 50s, a weathered old campaigner; and standing bac from the rest, watching from the side lines, SIR FRANCIS WALSINGHAM, the Queen's veteran friend and adviser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be warned by the atrocities in France! God-fearing Christians murdered by Papist cut-throats inflamed by hatred of the truth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know the Catholics take their                          orders from Spain. The Spanish                            speak openly of Mary Stuart as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen of England in waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Stuart is a Queen cast out by her own ungrateful nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With respect, majesty - a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catholic Queen. Your loyal Protestant supporters don't                               understand why Mary Stuart lives

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: under our protection, at our expense - very considerable                               expense -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Stuart is my cousin. She is                          our guest. And she is under our                           control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But while she lives, majesty, she                         is a beacon that draws our                                enemies' eyes and hopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While she lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is the poison at the heart of                         England. The poison must be cut                           out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have me make a martyr of                            her. What is her crime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 The Londoners on the river bank cheer and wave as the roy barge goes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treachery, ma'am. All Catholics                           are traitors! Their loyalty is to                         the Pope of Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many Catholics are there in England, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immense numbers, majesty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We believe half the nation clings                         to the old superstitions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you have me do? `Cut                           out' half the people of England?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must act, majesty. Our                                 inaction is taken to be weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If any of my people break the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: law, they will be punished. Until that day, I wish them to be let                           them alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until the day they rise in                                rebellion! Majesty, we have proven reason to fear every Catholic in the land -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear creates fear, sir. I will not punish my people for their beliefs. Only for their deeds. am assured that the people of England love their Queen. My constant endeavour is to earn that love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 Londoners on the river banks wave and cheer. Elizabeth, seated on the royal barge, sees them with satisfaction. S gives an occasional slight inclination of her head in acknowledgement. Elizabeth sits with her favourite seated beside her, her youngest and prettiest maid of honour, BESS THROCKMORTON. Walsingham sits facing them, looking sourly at the cheeri spectators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people are agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What people?

dialogues.speaker: WALSINGHAM
dialogues.text: Your bishops are preaching that                    God is showing his displeasure-                    the Queen being still unmarried -                  some are saying infertile -

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: WALSINGHAM
dialogues.text: Dangerous nonsense. Mary Stuart                    has a son -

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Why does everyone torment me with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Stuart? Pink Revision May 18- p.6 ELIZABETH(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not her fault that she's                       next in line to the throne.                         (to Bess)                                       Don't hide your face. She leans over to brush a stray lock of hair from Bess's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long as you have no issue.                       Elizabeth looks back at Wsalsingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Produce an heir and there'll be                     no more talk of Mary Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it customary to obtain a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: husband before producing an heir? (to Bess)                                       We shall have to look out a husband for you soon, Bess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too soon, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are husbands to be had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bess)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to be married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll want the marriage if I want the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Austria. France. Sweden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why stop there? Turkey has a                        Sultan. China has an Emperor.                       (to Bess)                                       What sort of man do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I confine myself to the possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An honest man. With friendly                        eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Walsingham)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where you and I differ,                            Walsingham. I find the impossible                         far more interesting.                                     (to Bess)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And good legs. You'll want good legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sweet breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that you can kiss him without choking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Walsingham)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be any amount of                               princes in undiscovered lands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: across the sea. Find me an honest one of those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The royal party enters the Cathedral. Elizabeth and Walsingham advance into the wide empty nave, followed by the Queen's ladies and the guards. Bess is now back in he place among the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ship builders are being recruited in Spanish ports at double wages. The sea wall at Dover is cracking. There's no money to rebuild our defences. I don't need advisers to tell me my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They care for your safety, majesty. The threats to your person are real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they know very well that if I fall, they all come tumbling down after me. She goes on to the steps at the foot of the altar, and kneels to pray. As she kneels she holds out one hand behi her, not looking round. Bess steps forward, and taking he hand, kneels and prays with her. Double Pink revision 18 July - p.8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's pray, Bess. May we have wisdom not to fear shadows in the night, and courage when the day of danger truly dawns. ON ELIZABETH as she prays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double Pink revision 18 July - p.9

dialogues.speaker: EXT THE TYGER, ENGLISH CHANNEL
dialogues.text: 11 Raleigh is standing on the prow of a war-ship as it cuts through the water toward the white cliffs of Dover. The ship and its sailors have been at sea for many months, an it shows. Raleigh shouts to his Sailing-Master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let England know we're back, Mr                           Calley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Gunner, run out starboard and tie-off. A broadside from the                         bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run out and prime. From the bow                           number one gun, on my word -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: discharge! Two -- Three-- Four. Canon fire echoes over the distant white cliffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 ON ELIZABETH - Imperfectly reflected in a mirror in the soft candlelight. Her ladies are putting her clothes away

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: Bess begins the process of stripping away her make-up. lizabeth studies her true face as it comes into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lines round my mouth. Where did they come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile lines, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile lines? When do I smile?                             With that she smiles, and sees Bess's answering reflected smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you have smile lines too.

dialogues.speaker: N
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p.10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her smile fades. She gazes at her now naked face, vulnerable in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: 13A
dialogues.text: The royal bed, immense and ornate. Elizabeth lies here small, awake, and alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Elizabeth! The angels weep for you, Elizabeth! Why do you close                          your ears to the voice of your                            loving God?'

dialogues.speaker: 13B
dialogues.text: Foresters at work felling great trees, working rhythmically, in pairs. From all round echoes the same sound, of axe on timber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Elizabeth! You are leading the souls of your people to Hell! Turn back! Marry me, and save England!'I spoke to her just as I speak to you now. ow we see the royal carriage riding through mature forest accompanied by a mounted entourage. IN THE CARRIAGE - The king, Philip II, the Infanta and Father Robert Reston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she did not listen. She made me a speech about the virtues of virginity. Me! Virginity! She has brought this on herself.

dialogues.speaker: P
dialogues.text: hilip surveys the scene through the carriage window with shudder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every tree that falls hurts me. I lose a part of myself. I am cursed with sensitivity. I feel too much. We don't yet know what the felling of the trees portends. But Reston does. To him, it's a glorious sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your majesty has a merciful soul. May 1 Blue Draft - p.11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sacrifice my country's forests to save the souls of a lost nation. That is true mercy. England is lost to darkness, Father. I bring light. WIDE NOW - We see the carriage and the royal party crest hill, and there is revealed an awesome sight: the forest has been felled as far as the eye can see. Great piles of cut timber dot the ravaged landscape. Everywhere men are work lopping branches from felled trees. Wagon teams haul immense trunks away. Fires burn stacks of lopped branches and the smoke rises up into the empty sky.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: N THE CARRIAGE - On Reston's face as he stares at the fires. He speaks half to himself, out of the depths of hi own fanatical certainty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light of purifying fire. He turns and fixes the king with his intent gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My time has come, majesty. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send me home.

dialogues.speaker: 13C
dialogues.text: Establishing wide shot of chartley Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 A small yapping Skye terrier is barking at a LAUNDRESS, w is handing over a letter, folded small, to a sharp-faced middle-aged French lady's maid, ANNETTE. The laundress curtseys and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 The terrier scampers ahead of Annette to its mistress, MA STUART, who sits embroidering a pink satin petticoat. She is a handsome but bitter woman in her mid-thirties. Round her stands her small retinue of three ladies and a chaplain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so pretty I'm inclined to send it as a present to my dear cousin Elizabeth. She holds up the delicate work to show her ladies. May 1 Blue Draft - p.12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is an intimate garment, of                         course. But even Elizabeth must                       have the occasional intimate                          moment.                                               Annette reaches her mistress and kneels before her, holdi out the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Queen. Mary lays down her needlework and takes the letter from h and reads it for herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our friends write to give us hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) Soon England's true believers will rise up against the bastard usurper Elizabeth, and slit her throat, and throw her down to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough, Annette. (But she loves it.) Slit her throat? Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when the bastard usurper is dead, my lady will be queen. The chaplain gives a sharp cough of warning. The Warden of Chartley Hall, SIR AMYAS PAULET, enters the room. He is soberly dressed, but has charming manners, an is clearly susceptible to his handsome ward. Mary turns t him at once with a teasing smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my noble jailer, come to                       smack my hand.                                        She holds out one hand to be smacked. The other hand hold the letter out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I sinned again, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, my lady. Unless beauty is                     counted a sin.                                        DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.13 PAULET(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Kissing her hand)                             I come to pay my respects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you jailer. I don't trust                      you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not jailer, my lady, please.                       Warden. Protector. Friend. You                     are the Queen's guest.                             Mary signs to her ladies. One of them brings her the embroidery, discreetly receiving in exchange the hidden letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See how I pass my time in my                       lonely prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charming, ma'am. Distractingly                     charming.                                          She holds the intimate garment against her body. Paulet seems to be too fascinated by it to notice he is being

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: duped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a pretty undergarment. But for whose eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 A pistol is being loaded: a fiddly process involving a powder horn, wadding, and an iron ball the size of a hazelnut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's it for, my young                               friend? Not for shooting rabbits,                        I'm guessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We live in dangerous times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do indeed. Savage moves close as if to study the loading process. We see the two of them talking from outside the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conspiracy gains strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell our master one of the circle has already gained access to the                         court.                                                   The Armourer nods. He hands the pistol to Savage. Savage takes it and leaves. Immediately after, a man enters and walks up behind the n seated Armourer. The Armourer turns round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask for your forgiveness.                              Moving with speed, he seizes the Armourer's head, twists to one side, and snaps his neck. Reston walks quietly out of the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 A crowd of eager SPECTATORS and WOULD-BE COURTIERS has gathered, held back by a line of guards, all hoping to attract the attention of the Queen when she appears. This is the route from the Presence Chamber to the Chapel Roya May 1 Blue Draft - p.15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every Sunday the Queen processes here, and crowds gather see her. Two of Walsingham's men, AGENTS 1 and 2, mingle the crowd: faces we'll see again. Tom Babington stands unobtrusively at the back of the crowd. He carries a bag which may or may not contain a gu

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: bustle of activity, a ripple of anticipation - `She's coming!' - and the palace doors open. BABINGTON'S POV: the crowd, the wall of BODYGUARDS, the cluster of COURTIERS and LADIES, and in their midst, Elizabeth, almost completely masked as she passes by. Alongside the Queen, among her maids-of-honour, is Bess Throckmorton; behind her, Walsingham. The people cheer, call out to the Queen, reach to touch her, fall to their knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless your majesty - God love you! - See her sweet face!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Others in the crowd are shouting more militant sentiments

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang the Papists! - Look out for traitors, Elizabeth! Mary Stuart                       is the whore of Rome!                                  Babington moves forward, easing his way to the front of t crowd. Nearby there stands another young man who is watching, not cheering: RAMSAY. A WOMAN WTH A BABY pushes her way almost to the Queen,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: holding her baby before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your blessing, majesty. My little one, your blessing.                                    BABINGTON'S POV- The Queen stopping to bless the little baby, smiling, putting out her hand to touch the baby's head. The mother bobs a curtsey. The Queen moves on, with her entourage. A sudden scuffle in the crowd. Babington turns to look. A CLOAK SWEEPS THROUGH FRAME - dropping down to the groun revealing as it passes the handsome smiling face of Raleigh, directly in R the path of the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A puddle in the way, majesty. Elizabeth signs to the guards to stay calm. She stares at Raleigh, then she looks down at the cloak. No sign of any puddles. Bess Throckmorton watches, suppressing a smile.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: Elizabeth looks back up, meets Raleigh's eyes with a cool appraising gaze. Then she walks on over the cloak, shakin her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A puddle... The guards take up their positions once more. Bess throws Raleigh a quick smile as she follows the royal party. His answering shrug says: I tried. He picks up the cloak, and stands gazing after the Queen. lizabeth goes into the chapel, and the doors close behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen is at her prayers!

dialogues.speaker: 18A
dialogues.text: The Queen at her prayers, her mind elsewhere; privately amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A puddle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh puts an arm round Calley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She spoke to me. You have to give me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I do. The Queen spoke to you. One word - but she spoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're made. A dukedom at the very least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the girl behind her? I've been at sea too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 The Great Hall is crowded with competing factions. A grou of Spaniards, led by their Ambassador, DON GUERAU DE SPES stand watching everyone else with haughty disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revision May 22--p.17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An architect waits to present details of a building project. Petitioners wait vainly, in the hope of catching the Queen's eye. Howard and Hatton are in attendance. Walsingham stands by the Queen's side, briefing her in a low murmur for her ears only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousands are dying every day of                    famine in Ireland. Another                          rebellion is a distinct                             possibility.                                        A courtier is holding a portrait which he shows to the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis of Valois, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother to the king of France, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: France is in religious turmoil. It would be unwise to engage with                   their instability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lord Howard)                                You have the plans for the new docks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard beckons the Architect forward to show his model. Elizabeth studies it. Walsingham murmurs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still need to keep France out                    of the arms of Spain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me think on it.                                 (to Howard)                                     What if enemy ships should sail up the Thames? Can the docks be closed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not closed, majesty. But the gun                    positions here, and here, have                      full command of the channel.                        The courtier displays a second portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King Erik of Sweden, majesty.                       Yellow Revision May 22--p.17A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still madly in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still mad, you mean. (Looking                      around). Where's Bess?                             The courtier presents a third portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ivan, Tsar of all the Russias,                     known as "The Terrible."                           Walsingham merely shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buff revision 6th June- p.18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 Bess Throckmorton is late. She comes running through the crowd of lesser petitioners who wait in the hope of gaini access to the Queen. She passes Calley, the two native Americans, and a group of sailors holding large hampers. Raleigh is trying to persuade the doorkeeper to let him past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to see the Lord                             Chamberlain, sir.                                       He indicates a portly man surrounded by petitioners, beyo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the open doors to the inner rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I to see him if you won't let me through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must wait for him to come out, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when will he come out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way of knowing that,                         sir.                                                    The doorkeeper stands aside for Bess. She recognises Raleigh, and throws him a smile before rushing past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if to Calley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had less trouble than this boarding a Spanish ship!                                Everything is easier when you can                       kill people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 Bess curtseys before Elizabeth; who shakes her head at he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late again, Bess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your majesty's forgiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given. Once. Buff revision 6th June- p.18A

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: The puddle man is outside, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revision May 22-- p.19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth takes Bess's arm and turns with her to the portraits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My suitors. The Courtier has a fourth portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Archduke Charles of Austria,                   majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The younger brother of Maximilian II, the Holy Roman Emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cousin of Philip II of Spain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's rather sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More your age than mine, Bess. How old is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young... I believe, majesty. An

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Austrian alliance would keep France quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it would put Philip on a                       leash.                                             Elizabeth looks across at the Spaniards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I become almost enthusiastic. to Hatton)                                    Send for him. (to Bess) Where is he, then? Bess understands. She bobs and hurries to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Walsingham) How much longer do you think I can play this game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virginity is an asset that holds its value well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diplomatically speaking. Yellow Revision May 22 - p.19A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh now enters with Calley, the native Americans and court servants carrying hampers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revision May 22 - p.20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Spaniards recognises him and murmurs to the Ambassador; who speaks angrily to the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, this man is a notorious pirate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed? Don Guerau points to the hampers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanish treasure, stolen from Spanish ships. You will see.

dialogues.speaker: R
dialogues.text: aleigh kneels before the Queen. Elizabeth gestures for hi to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Raleigh, your majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes. Raleigh. I've heard of your voyage. What's your rank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gentleman of Devon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The honour to be in the presence of my Queen, whose radiant beauty is the boast and glory of the English people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just returned from the New World, majesty. I have claimed the fertile coast in your name, and called it Virginia, in honour of our Virgin Queen. Elizabeth raises her eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virginia? And if I marry? Will you change the name to Conjugia? A royal joke. Her entourage laughs dutifully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Revision May 22 -p.21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask for your gracious permission, majesty, to return to the New World with your royal warrant, to found a colony under the laws and protections of England.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: lizabeth's eye has fallen on the native Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Americans, majesty. They long to                      be your newest subjects. He beckons Calley to lead Wanchese and Manteo forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have they no ruler of their own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None to match England's Queen. Elizabeth gazes at the natives. She holds out her hand. Unaware that he's meant to kiss the Queen's hand, Manteo, takes it and shakes it. A gasp from the watching courtier But Elizabeth accepts the courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These gentlemen are welcome. See that they're treated well. Calley hurries them away before worse happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also come bearing gifts for your majesty, from the New World. He beckons to the servants to bring the baskets. Don Guer steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fruits of piracy, majesty. The true property of the realm of Spain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see, shall we? to Raleigh) What do you bring me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mud, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: R
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p.22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Members of the court share suppressed smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Mud and leaves? aleigh throws open the first basket. Don Guerau peers inside suspiciously. It does indeed seem to be filled wit mud. Raleigh takes out a potato beneath the Ambassador's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patata, majesty. You eat it. Very nourishing. He beckons forward the second basket, which is full of leaves. Again Don Guerau tracks his every move. He takes out a tobacco leaf. R

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tobacco. You breathe its smoke. Very stimulating. Now Don Guerau realises he's being laughed at on all side He draws himself up with angry pride, wrinkling his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, majesty, I find the air has become stale. I am sensitive to the smell of open sewers. A glare at Raleigh, a bow for the Queen, and Don Guerau leads his Spaniards out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Raleigh) Continue. With a broad smile, Raleigh gestures forward the third basket. This one really is full of gold. He takes out a gold coin and presents it to Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold. You spend it. Very satisfying. Elizabeth examines the fat gold coin, with its image of Philip of Spain. She tries not to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Courtesy of a Spanish ship, that found itself unable to complete its journey. Elizabeth drops the gold coin back into the basket. Green Revision May 25 - p.23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fruits of piracy after all,                           it seems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philip of Spain is no friend of England, majesty. The more gold I take from him, the safer you will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well. A political pirate. A logic-chopping pirate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your majesty's most loyal subject. She gives him a long look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not my best dressed. W    (Beat) elcome home, Mr Raleigh. She turns her attention back to Hatton and the portraits. Raleigh bows and withdraws, followed by his men. Walsingh follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 Raleigh comes out into the hallway with Calley by his sid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think of her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But magnificent.                                          He moves on. Raleigh's eyes fall on Don Guerau, the Spanish Ambassador passing near with his fellow Spaniards and a few English courtiers and ministers, including Hatton. Don Guerau stares at him. The doors to the privy chamber open and the Queen's ladie come swishing out in a tight chattering group, Bess besid her friend MARGARET. May 1 Blue Draft - p.24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Mud and leaves'! I nearly died!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Patata! You eat it!' They giggle as they go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She liked him. I could tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, wouldn't you? They see Raleigh now, and the chatter ceases. The ladies come to a stop and curtsey. Raleigh gives a bow, his eyes singling out Bess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to have the opportunity to thank you. Without your help, I'd still be in outer darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did very little, sir. You'd already caught the Queen's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I thank you for the very little. The ladies go on their way and the laughing chatter resumes, with many a backward glance at the handsome Raleigh. No one pays attention to a figure in the shadows another of Walsingham's men, AGENT 3. 23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Savage stands alone among trees, shivering, white- faced, half-mumbling, half-singing an endless prayer. He holds a pistol with which he means to kill himself. But h can't do it.         S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salve regina, mater misericordiae, vita dulcedo et spes nostra salve... In a clearing nearby three men sit round a fire. They are young Catholic fanatics - Babington, Ramsay, and FRANCIS THROCKMORTON. A fourth man stands before them, his back t us, watching Savage. At first we don't see who he is. May 1 Blue Draft - p.25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His weakness endangers us all. He can't go on with us. And we can't leave him behind. Now the man turns and looks intently at Babington, and we see he is Robert Reston; no longer in the clothes of a priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who will help him? Babington rises. Reston nods his approval. Babington goes off through the trees. Reston and the others follow a little behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: singing) Ad te clamamus, exsulaes filii Evae. Ad te suspiramus gementes et flentes in hac lacrimarum valle - He sings on as Babington approaches him, seeming no longe to know what's happening. Babington takes the pistol from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make your peace with God. Savage stares, and suddenly realises what Babington means to do. Terror overwhelms him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Tom! Don't kill me! I don't want to die! Now he's blubbering with fear. Babington is shaken by thi and can't shoot. Reston begins to pray aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si ambulam in medio umbrae mortis, non timebo mala - The others join in with the words of the well-known psalm Babington too joins in, now weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoniam tu mecum es, Domine. Virga tua et baculus tuus, ipsa me consolata sunt -

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: ANG! Savage falls dead.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p.26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 Walsingham enters his private home, and gives his hat and cloak to his servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visitor waiting, sir. Walsingham frowns. He climbs the stairs to the door of hi study. There, pacing nervously, is his younger brother WILLIAM, a middle-aged student. Walsingham's scowl disappears. He opens his arms wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Francis. They embrace. Then Walsingham pushes him back to take a good look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look terrible. Don't they feed you in Paris? How are your studies? Learned the secrets of the universe yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are dangerous times to be questioning the ways of God. You must take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My needs are simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll dine with us? You'll lodge with us? is daughter MARY appears at the top of the next flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William! She comes tumbling down and into his arms. She's an eager innocent 20-year-old, much loved by her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you! All grown up. URSULA, Walsingham's wife, appears as Mary leads William the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: M
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p.27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William. This is a pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been away too long, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come with me, William. ary and William go on into the family's living rooms. Ursula meets her husband's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not still a student, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 William is by the fire, listening to Mary playing the virginal and singing. Walsingham and Ursula are by the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you spoken to the Queen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I speak to her daily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. You've done enough. No man could do more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't leave court yet. The Queen needs me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're to die in harness like a pack horse, are you? And for what? (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary! William!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are difficult times-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always difficult times.                             Mary joins them, her arm in William's. Walsingham seizes the opportunity to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William, come and tell us all the                        new ideas in the University. Will                        the great breach in the church                           ever be healed?                                          May 1 Blue Draft - p.28

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I doubt it, brother. Compromise                    is out of fashion. On both sides                   they say there can only be one                     truth, and one God.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: Sit, sit.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: ere by me, William.

dialogues.speaker: WALSINGHAM
dialogues.text: What do they say in Paris of the                   Pope's call for holy war?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Many welcome it.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: I don't understand why we must all hate each other.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Truth will always hate falsehood, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why do we have to talk about war? Tell us your nice news, William. Are you married yet?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (smiling) Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then we must find you a nice sensible English wife.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, no. I won't be staying long. I must go back to my studies.

dialogues.speaker: WALSINGHAM
dialogues.text: Not too soon, I hope. Every man deserves a rest.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: Listen to him! When did you last rest, I'd like to know? (to William) He won't listen to me. Not a thought for his health. You tell him, he's your brother. He'll die at his desk, out of sheer selfishness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revision May 25 - p.29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsingham shares a rueful smile with William that says, `Women, eh?'. They take their seats for dinner. 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 Elizabeth sits sumptuously gowned and jewelled at an ornately-dressed dining table, surrounded by her ladies, Bess among them; Walsingham discreetly in the background. They're listening to a young Austrian make a formal speec of love. The AUSTRIAN AMBASSADOR stands to one side, mouthing the words to prompt him. The ARCHDUKE CHARLES is still a boy: sixteen years old, slight, pale, trembling with shyness. He struggles throug his rehearsed speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your majesty's beauty is dazzling to my eyes. Your learning is                              famed throughout Europe. I see                            before me perfection in human

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: form. Oh, Elizabeth! How blessed am I to stand in your fabled                              presence, warmed by your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: greatness as by the rays of the sun. Oh Elizabeth! To speak your                          name is to hear celestial music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May that sweet sound guide me through my life to come -                                 Elizabeth! Elizabeth! I have

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: travelled here, to this illustrious court, in the hope                            that our two great nations might

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: be joined in love. But now that I am bathed in the radiance of your                         glory, I am overwhelmed. I am

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: conquered. I die. Only your love, great Elizabeth, can restore me to life.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: ourtiers exchange smiles at his efforts. The Spaniards sneer openly. But Elizabeth takes the charade with due gravity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your highness does me great honour. Shall we eat our dinner?                          It should prove almost as restorative as my love. Raleigh enters the Great Hall, trailed by Calley, as the dinner gets under way. They join the much larger group wh simply stand and watch. Royal meals are in part a spectac for the court. A JESTER moves from group to group, playin pranks on the guests. Green Revision May 25 - p.29A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh is now dressed in court fashion, and looks very well; as the glances of several court ladies show. He catches Bess's eye and they share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me, Mr Raleigh, in your sea battles - how do you sink an enemy ship? You shoot holes in its sides, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p.30

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. A sunk ship is of no value. The object is to capture and command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise. Speed. Irresistible violence. Calley, listening, rolls his eyes. Elizabeth, at the table with the Archduke by her side, glances towards Raleigh, and sees him flirting with the court ladies. Then back to the young Archduke, who has hardly touched his food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're not as accustomed as I am to eating in public. I have a secret. lowering her voice) I pretend there's a pane of glass - eine Glasscheibe - between me and them.

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: he moves one hand before her face, indicating an imaginar pane of glass. As she looks, she sees Bess staring at someone - follows her gaze - and is amused to find that t object of her attention is also Raleigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can see me, but they can't hear me, or touch me. You should try it. She beckons to Bess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess. Bess comes forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) He interests me. Talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him, my lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him. Bess turns and looks across towards Raleigh, as he flirts with the court ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Revision May 25 - p.31

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth turns back to her guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His highness is tired after his journey. The young Archduke, frozen with shyness, sits staring before him, trembling as he frames a proper reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No man can be tired in the presence of so lovely a Queen.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: lizabeth speaks so only he can hear, in German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (You play the game very well, my young friend. But don't you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sometimes feel an overwhelming desire to say what you're really                   thinking?)                                         The Archduke's eyes open very wide. He glances at Elizabeth, and sees on her face a conspiratorial smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (I daren't even think what I'm                     really thinking.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (You're thinking, perhaps, that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you would far rather be home.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (You're very wise, madame.) He's grateful to her, and his shy face shows it. Raleigh is still being entertained by the court ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I adore the natives you brought back with you. I don't suppose                     you could get one for me? They're                  not dangerous, are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends what you propose to                   do with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd dress him up in mulberry-                      coloured silk and have him walk                    behind me, carrying my cloak.                     Green Revision May 25 - p.31A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess has now approached Raleigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pirate is not too bored by the vanities of the court, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple sailor, dazzled by the bright lights. Bess draws him away from the court ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can bring yourself to leave the dazzle of the bright lights for a moment - May 1 Blue Draft - p.32

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: rawn away by the brightest light of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That can only mean the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't presume to raise my eyes so high. They both look at the Queen. She's watching Raleigh. He bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems you've presumed after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems you're determined to think the worst of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what it is you really want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What every man wants. Money. Fame. Love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each leads to the next. The money will buy and equip ships for a return voyage to the New World. The success of my infant colony there will make me famous. The fame will bring me love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems rather a long way round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are benefits along the way. It is something, after all, to take a blank on the map and build there a shining city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which you will no doubt name after yourself. May 1 Blue Draft - p.33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) No doubt. B

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then. I am answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask a question in return?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I to win the Queen's favour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I tell you that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've little enough to offer, I know. But whatever I have to give - ask, and it's yours. Bess thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My advice to you is, say what you mean to say as plainly as possible. All men flatter the Queen in the hope of advancement. Pay her the compliment of truth. She gives him her hand. He kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Throckmorton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone calls me Bess.

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: he goes back to the Queen, as Elizabeth is rising to leave. She speaks to the company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His highness the Archduke informs me that my charms overwhelm him. He will retire to his private quarters to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This causes much amusement. Don Guerau sneers openly. The Archduke rises. All rise. The Archduke bows solemnly to t Queen, and leaves with his entourage. Elizabeth beckons t Walsingham, and speaks low to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a sweet boy. I don't want him hurt by your schemes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 Bess is reading to Elizabeth. Elizabeth watching her, her mind elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suspect him of being a professional charmer. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is certainly charming, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are duller professions. And what is it he hopes to gain by his charms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hopes for glory in his New World. He dreams of building a shining city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which I'm to pay for, no doubt. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like him, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's refreshing to meet a man who                        looks to a world beyond the                              court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it is. We shall let him come                          again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 Mary Stuart holds her pet dog in her arms, listening to Annette, who kneels before her. May 1 Blue Draft - p. 35

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dismissed? On whose orders? She looks up at the laundress, who stands red-eyed and snuffling, with a guard by her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do stop snivelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Warden, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Warden? My Warden? As she speaks, Sir Amyas Paulet enters. Mary's voice becomes seductive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done now, you bad                       man? Sent away my laundress? How                      am I to have clean clothes? Or do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you want me to go about naked? Paulet smiles at the notion of Mary naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was not my motive, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much though - (Thinking better of it)                           Your laundress was found to be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: carrying letters in her washing. Not her job, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I to send my intimate                          letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you will read them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With respectful admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I to have no privacy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.                                                   Beneath the charm, steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You disappoint me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p. 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen orders these measures                       for your protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen! Am I not a Queen too?                      What if I wish to write a love                        letter? Is Elizabeth to be sent a                     copy? Is she so starved of lovers                     that she must feed on mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen grieved when your                           husband died, ma'am. As she                           grieved when your second husband

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: died. And the third. If there is a possibility of a fourth -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tormentor! Is that Elizabeth's                        order too? That you torment and                       mock me?                                              She turns to go, but stops before leaving the room: bitte haughty, not deigning to look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say she's a beautiful woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she so very beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't presume to comment on the Queen's person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's called the virgin queen.                        Why is that, sir? Can it be that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: no man will have her? Mary changes mood again, thinking it more politic to keep the Warden under her spell. She waves Annette and the laundress away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend, forgive me. You are my friend, are you not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am your servant, ma'am, and your admirer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall send no more letters. I shall stay here quietly, in my prison. With you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p. 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 The same crowd of petitioners wait in vain for access to the Queen. The same door keeper. Raleigh enters, and this time the door keeper bows, and ushers him through the ope doors. Over this we hear Raleigh's voice telling of his adventures:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It begins with a journey. You must cross an ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 Elizabeth listens attentively, her eyes looking far away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: into the distance, as Raleigh tells of his adventures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you imagine - can you feel - what it is to cross an ocean? For                         weeks you see nothing but the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: horizon. All round you. Perfect, and empty. Your ship is small -                           tiny - a speck in such immensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 Walsingham is talking to Elizabeth about matters of state We are on her face, and we can see that she hears nothing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of what he tells her. Her mind is all on Raleigh's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live with fear, in the grip                           of fear - fear of storms, fear of                         sickness on board, fear of the                            immensity. What if you never                              escape? How can you escape?                               There's nowhere to go. So you                             must drive your fear down, deep                           into your belly, and study your                           charts, and watch your compass,                           and pray for a fair wind - and                            hope.

dialogues.speaker: 33A
dialogues.text: Now Elizabeth is with Raleigh again, listening as he goes on speaking to her, now directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 May 1 Blue Draft - p. 38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pure naked fragile hope, when all                        your senses scream at you, Lost!                         Lost! Imagine it. Day after day,                         staring west, the rising sun on                          your back, the setting sun in                            your eyes, hoping, hoping -                              Sir Christopher Hatton enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, the Archduke and the                            court are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them wait! (to Raleigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Mr Raleigh. You were hoping. Hatton bows and leaves, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first it's no more than a haze on the horizon, the ghost of a haze, the pure line corrupted. But clouds do that, and storms. So you watch, you watch. 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth dances with Raleigh. As they dance, his voice continues over; and Elizabeth seems to be listening to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's a smudge, a shadow on the far water. For a day, for another day, the stain slowly spreads along the horizon, and takes form - until on the third day you let yourself believe. You dare to whisper the word - land! The music ends, and the dance finishes. Elizabeth is seated now - it's later in time. Raleigh is speaking intently to her, and she is captivated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Land. Life. Resurrection. The true adventure. Coming out of the vast unknown, out of the immensity, into safe harbour at last. That - that - is the New World.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p. 39

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short silence. Elizabeth is absorbing what he has told her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen does not have a private                         life.

dialogues.speaker: INT PRESENCE CHAMBER, WHITEHALL PALACE
dialogues.text: 35 Elizabeth is on the throne. The Archduke Charles and his entourage face her. The court fills the room. Elizabeth makes her formal response to the young Archduke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen lives for her people. You will therefore forgive me, sir, if after much thought and prayer I decline your offer of marriage. The Archduke, barely able to conceal his relief, turns to the Austrian ambassador.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Can I go home now?) Elizabeth inclines her head, trying not to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Go home, my friend. Don't be in a hurry to grow old. Youth is so very precious.) Elizabeth rises and takes the Archduke's arm as they star to leave the chamber. Bess, in her wake, finds an opportunity to speak softly to Raleigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? Are you satisfied with the                          Queen's favour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She listened as if she understood me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I shall expect some gratitude. R

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want? Their eyes meet, both aware of the current of mutual attraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p. 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect I'll think of something. Bess hurries after the Queen. The Austrian entourage is just leaving as the Queen turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Raleigh.

dialogues.speaker: 35A
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Raleigh walk together around the perimeter hallway, dwarfed by vast murals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your immensities. Your ocean is an image of eternity, I think. Such great spaces make us small. Do we discover the New World, Mr Raleigh, or does the New World discover us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak like a true explorer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you, Mr Raleigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I like you. She stops and turns to meet Raleigh's eyes. She's not use to such direct replies. Bess is watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, of course, that when I like a man, I reward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what have you to say about it?       R

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reward my mission, majesty, not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the mission not the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me free to like you in return. That can be my reward. 41-43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it must be hard for so great a Queen to know the simple pleasure of being liked for herself. Elizabeth stares. This is a little too close to the truth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you become dull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horses racing, hoofs pounding over the grass, manes flyin Two riders hurtle between the trees, down a woodland ride neck and neck- Elizabeth and Raleigh are racing against each other, face glowing, laughing, abandoned to the breakneck speed of th moment. Raleigh is winning now, first by a head, then by a length At the end of the ride he slows his horse to a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine! Elizabeth shakes her head, unable to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have - the stronger horse.

dialogues.speaker: Y RALEIGH
dialogues.text: ours carries the lighter load.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen does not give way to                           others.                                                  Raleigh stops his horse. Elizabeth rides on up to him and then past him. Raleigh secretly spurs his horse. The hors springs forward, ahead of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Whoa!                                              (at Elizabeth, reigning                              in the horse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, majesty. My horse                            doesn't know his place yet                               Elizabeth looks at him, amused, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever known your place,                     Mr. Raleigh?                                        She urges her horse forward, forcing Raleigh to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised you're not married                    yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a sailor, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And can sailors not be lovers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must lovers be husbands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I see. You like love better

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: than marriage. That I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your majesty is not eager to be married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I marry, I marry for my                        country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Raleigh) When I love, I love for myself.                     (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have had many loves, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Some...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've yet to meet your equal?                      Raleigh hesitates. She understands him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would want someone who knows me                   as I am.                                            Now it is Elizabeth who hesitates. He understands her as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a friend, not just an equal. You want someone to share                    your joy when you're happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double Blue - july 8 - p.43B ELIZABETH(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone to cry with when you're                           sad. Someone to talk to when                              there's nothing to say. Someone                           to find by your side when you                             wake in the night. Someone who                            remembers what you once were,                             when you've grown old.                                    She turns to him with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah yes. I know all about it.                              There. I'm rested now.                                    She turns her horse around in the direction from which th came. Raleigh follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can be something to each

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: other, I hope, Mr. Raleigh. She spurs her horse, and suddenly she's racing away, back across the park to the distant band of mounted courtiers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and Queen's ladies, including Bess. Raleigh spurs his hor to follow, also fast, but this time careful to keep a distance behind. As they near the courtiers, Raleigh splits off. Bess watches as Elizabeth turns and looks after him as he ride 3 away. 6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess creeps out of her bedroom, pulling on a cloak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 Bess makes her way down the dark palace corridor, steppin over sleeping courtiers as she goes. Margaret watches her from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Cloaked and hooded, Bess passes quietly down an alley, stepping over more sleeping forms. London's homeless. She finds a door, checks a note she holds, glances round be sure no one sees her, knocks and enters.

dialogues.speaker: INT LONDON HOUSE
dialogues.text: 39 A man closes the door behind his visitor. Bess shakes off her hood. It's George Throckmorton, one of the conspirators. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double Blue - july 8 - p.43C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George! What's wrong? Is your                        father alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's old. He won't live long now.                    Thank you for coming, dear Bess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was worried. You must send me                      no more letters. You know what                       would happen if I was caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need more money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father is a tired old man. We                     don't want to hide like this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: anymore. We both want to get back to court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are known Papists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen loves you. Speak to                        her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot betray the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not betraying her. My

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: father and I will embrace the new faith.                                               Bess is suspicious and starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't put me in danger like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin Bess, we've known each other all our lives. I would do                      nothing to harm you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they catch us, they will kill                     us. Our lives are in your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double Blue - july 8 - p.43D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 A group of the Queen's ladies make their way down the hallway, Bess among them. The others are gossiping in low whispers as they go. Bess is silent with anxiety. Then she looks ahead, and her face fills with fear. Walsingham is coming down the hallway towards them. The ladies curtsey. He nods, and throws a glance at Bess. The ladies move on. Bess looks back. Walsingham is also looking back, and see to be watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 Bess hurries ahead of the others through the Privy Chambe to the Queen's private quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ess passes ladies organising the Queen's wardrobe. She finds the Queen laughing with Raleigh - not alone, but unusually informal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tease me, Mr Raleigh. There's nothing I'd like to do more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, then. I will. He blinks: caught by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See! You lie! You don't want me on your ship at all. (turning towards Bess)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a liar! Elizabeth now takes in Bess.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: Green revision May 25 -p.44

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to go to sea, Bess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that's not possible. Women bring bad luck on board ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, do they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock up a hundred men in a space smaller than this room, for months at a time - Men have needs. A beautiful woman like you would drive us all mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men have needs? nce again Elizabeth meets Raleigh's eyes. Then she breaks away, feeling the contact is dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let them stay on land and see to their needs. (to Bess)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Raleigh is eager to sail away to his infant colony, Bess. We must persuade him to stay a little longer, mustn't we?

dialogues.speaker: 42A
dialogues.text: Raleigh is leaving. Walsingham has been waiting for him. falls into step beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Raleigh. A word of advice. The Queen chooses to show you favour. You naturally wish to take advantage of that. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask for too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think all I want is money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope all you want is money. Buff Revision 6th June - p.44A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm a cynical                                   adventurer, with little breeding                          and less education. You're wrong.                         I'm a cynical adventurer with                             little breeding and an excellent                          education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I begin to see why the Queen                              likes you.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. LONDON HOUSE
dialogues.text: 43 A soft knock on the door. Francis Throckmorton goes to th window and looks out. THROCKMORTON'S POV - In the street outside, a woman with her head covered. He unbolts the door. T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess? Two men burst in and seize him. They are Agents 4 and 5. Beyond, the woman - not Bess - is hurrying away. Throckmorton struggles. A single sharp blow, and he folds to the ground. 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 Multiple images of Elizabeth, naked. Strange misty refracted glimpses of her face, her body. A bath of steaming hot water has been placed in the Queen private quarters, and screened by mirrors. The Queen is i the bath, being washed by her ladies.

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: ess Throckmorton has the job of holding the Queen's hair out of the water as she's washed. She strokes the soft tresses as she holds them, unaware that Elizabeth can see her in the mirror. Then she looks up and catches Elizabeth's eyes, and stops in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't stop. I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess returns to her gentle caresses, and Elizabeth to her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true, Bess? That I've never known the simple pleasure of being liked for myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you believe that I like                           you for yourself, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anybody ever liked just for themselves? Are you? I doubt it. Men like you because you're pretty. And because you have the ear of the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft - p. 50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him too. He likes you because he wants my favour. You do realise that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the other thing too, of course. But all men want that. Male desire confers no B         distinction. ess strokes Elizabeth's hair in silence. Then she sees Elizabeth gazing at her in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
