dialogues.text: I envy you, Bess. You're free to have - what I can't have. You're my adventurer. Don't be afraid. It's all over so soon. 46

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who looks like a shop assistant sits grabbing a qui lunch. He's the TORTURER. Nearby on a blood-stained bench lies a huddled half-naked figure, trembling uncontrollabl It's Francis Throckmorton. He's neither manacled nor guarded. His body is so broken it's not necessary. Walsingham enters. The torturer jumps to his feet. Walsingham goes to Throckmorton. He gazes at him, shaking his head. He's getting too old for this dirty business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still nothing to tell me, Mr Throckmorton? Throckmorton struggles to lift his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My soul will go free soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know about the Enterprise. I need names. But if you won't help me, perhaps your father will. He signs to the torturer. The torturer goes into an adjoining cell. orchid revisions 28 June - p. 51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been questioned, as you have. I do have to know, you see. The torturer and a guard enter, dragging between them the broken but living body of OLD THROCKMORTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Old Throckmorton looks up, eyes blank with suffering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough! You want a name, I'll give you a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? Walsingham comes close to hear. Throckmorton chokes out something we don't hear, but the torturer hears, and his eyes open wide.

dialogues.speaker: 46A
dialogues.text: orchid revisions 28 June - p. 52

dialogues.speaker: 46B
dialogues.text: Elizabeth passes down a hallway at a brisk pace, Hatton b her side, her ladies hurrying behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another letter has come from Mary Stuart, majesty. Asking to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filled with declarations of love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she wants my love, let her deserve it. Refused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 Elizabeth enters her private quarters, now moving with regal dignity once more, but the flush on her cheeks give her away. Her ladies follow. There stands Raleigh, waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Raleigh. I've kept you waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have more important concerns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is always other business. But I have been waiting too. Walsingham enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty. Elizabeth turns on him with a frown of irritation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Walsingham?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The traitor has talked, majesty. The traitor Throckmorton. orchid revisions 28 June - p. 52A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flash of fear in Bess's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Raleigh) Forgive me, sir. As you see, my time is not my own. Elizabeth moves away so that Walsingham can talk to her i confidence. She listens to his murmured words, and anger shows on her face.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 The torturer, now off duty, is standing in the open doorw to empty his bladder. He's unlacing his britches, when he hears footsteps approaching behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry? The torturer begins to piss, with evident pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never guess what I heard - A knife at his throat. A quick slash. The killer, Agent 3, waits one more moment, to be sure th job is done. The torturer slumps, still standing, against the wall. Agent 3 slips away. On the flag stones, blood trickles down to mingle with th urine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 Now there are guards everywhere. The whole palace is on heightened alert. lizabeth sweeps out of the Privy Chamber into the Great Hall, accompanied by the Spanish Ambassador on one side a Walsingham on the other. Her entourage scuttles behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know of the Enterprise of England, Ambassador?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Enterprise...? Forgive me, your majesty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a plan for the invasion of my country. Two armies landing on the coasts of Sussex and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norfolk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Norfolk. Mary Stuart is to be set free, and placed on the English throne. May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 54 ELIZABETH(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am to be assassinated. Does any of this sound familiar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know nothing of any invasion plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I refer to this plan as the Enterprise of England. It should more accurately be called `la Empresa di Inglaterra', because it's a Spanish plan. The plan of your king, my one-time brother-in- law, Philip II, to attack my country. The Ambassador decides the best form of defence is attack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attack? It is my country that is under attack! Your so-called pirates attack our merchant ships daily! Do you think we don't know where their orders come from? The whole world knows that pirates sail up the Thames all the way to the royal bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) You will leave my presence, sir! Go back to Spain! Tell Philip that I don't fear him, or his priests, or his armies. Tell him if he wants to shake his little fist at us, we're ready to give him such a bite he'll wish he'd kept his hands in his pockets. Don Guerau sees no point in further pretence. He speaks with pride and contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see a leaf fall, and you think you know which way the wind blows. But a wind is coming, madam, that will sweep away your pride.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: e bows and turns to go. Elizabeth's words blaze after him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I too can command the wind, sir. I have a hurricane in me that will strip Spain bare, if you dare to try me! May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shivering with rage she turns round, and there's Raleigh. Her fury overflows onto him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you staring at? Lower your eyes! I am the Queen! She sweeps past him without a further glance. ON RALEIGH - Watching Elizabeth go. A shake of his head. Enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 Immense stacks of cut timber as far as the eye can see. Skeletons of new ships, big ships, rising in the great yard. Hundreds of ship-builders at work.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: his is what the forests were felled for: a brand-new flee is being built. Tiny figures in the wide scene: the royal party appears. Philip has come to see progress for himself. As he and hi entourage tour the construction site, one of his minister briefs him on the latest developments in England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (It can't be denied that we've lost the advantage of surprise. A large part of our plans has come into their hands.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The Jesuit is still at liberty?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (We understand so, majesty.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He knows his business. We've lost nothing.) The workmen kneel to Philip as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Tell the carpenters to go on working. No one is to stop for me. The fleet must be ready to sail in a month.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Impossible, majesty!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (If this is God's work, God will make it possible.)

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a miracle -)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A miracle, then. Let it be done!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 LOSE ON pen and paper - a letter being written in haste. Raleigh at a ship's table littered with charts. He's writing a letter to the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calley enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visitor for you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: 51A
dialogues.text: The Tyger is in dock. Raleigh emerges from his cabin to find Bess waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen has sent you to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the Queen that I will

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: trouble her no more. As soon as my ship's repairs are complete I will ask permission to sail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen asks me to assure you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need no assurances. I'm no courtier and never have been. I've lost my appetite for playing games that it seems I'm too stupid to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is unfair -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call me unfair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me speak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh is taken aback by Bess's sudden anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen shouts at you once, and                         you sulk like a child. I thought                          you more of a man than that. And                          I thought you a better friend to                          the Queen. Her every move is                              watched by a hundred eyes.                                Assassins plot to kill her.                               Enemies prepare to overwhelm her                          country. And you say she's                                playing games?                                            Raleigh is watching her as she speaks, and he's impressed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anger suits her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. What is my Queen's command?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to her, sir. As her friend. 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is pacing, disturbed, Raleigh's letter open in her hand. The doors open. Raleigh enters. Elizabeth waits for the servants to close the doors behind him. Holds up the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask permission to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You plan to return to the New                             World. To your colony. For two,                           or three, or four years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your majesty grants me your                            royal warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing left for me to do                         here. At sea I know what I'm to                           do, I know the risks, I know the                          rewards. Here -                                           May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shrug. What can he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're quite wrong. You are needed here. I have decided to appoint you Captain of my personal guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain of your - !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kneel. He kneels. She taps him on the shoulder with one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise, Sir Walter Raleigh. He rises, but keeps his eyes on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? You may express your gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is too great an honour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's such an honour, why are                       you staring at your boots?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why.                                         He raises his eyes, but he still doesn't look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you stare at the wall. Am I so old and hideous that you can't even look me in the face? He turns now, and looks her in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you talk like a fool when you're anything but a fool? This stops her in her tracks. For a moment she can't trus herself to speak. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend, forgive me. I'm a vain and foolish woman. At court it's all a game. I like to be admired. I require it. I grow accustomed to it. But it's all - nothing.

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: 5 May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 59 ELIZABETH(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come here as if from another world, and I - You have real adventures, you go where the maps end. I would follow you there if I could, believe me.                                     Raleigh looks long into her eyes. If anything, he admires and loves her all the more now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm clouds are gathering,                          my friend. Please don't leave me                         now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 CLOSE ON Throckmorton as the noose is tightened round his neck. His face is ravaged by the tortures he's endured, b he holds his head high, ready for death. Round him an unseen crowd bays for blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang! Hang! Hang!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord have mercy on the soul of your servant, who gives his life for your eternal truth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 A candle-lit cellar, where Reston and the conspirators pr for the condemned man, heads bowed. abington bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis is about to die! We must                         act!      R

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters heaven as a soldier                            returns home victorious from war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we strike? What's he dying for? Is this part of your plan? Reston puts his hands on Babington's shoulders and gently but irresistibly forces him down to pray with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, be with us as the end approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 60 RESTON(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will not fail in our duty. We look beyond death, to eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 Throckmorton drops. His body flails. His neck breaks. A roar of bloodlust from the crowd. (RENUMBERED- SEE SCENE 51A)

dialogues.speaker: 55B
dialogues.text: Bess is on her knees before the simple altar, her head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bowed in prayer. Raleigh enters through the rear doors. He stands in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: silence, watching her as she prays. He hears her sigh. He takes a step towards her. She hears, startled. Turns a sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! It's you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My prayer's done. She rises to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something has distressed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I thought I prayed in                                silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away, unable to look him in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man was hanged today. A Papist.                        I knew him well. He was my                               cousin. He died because I gave                           information. I gave information                          to prove my loyalty. Because I                           was afraid.                                              May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's necessity. That's the world we live in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me he wanted to change. Become part of the new England. I was afraid that he was lying to me. But what if - what if it was true? He sees the horror in her eyes, at the thought that she h sent an innocent man to his death. Tears rise to her eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I was his last hope? What if I was the one person he thought he could trust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you knew him well, you will have sensed the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was hoping to use you. You did

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: what you had to do. She can no longer hold back the tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, now. He wipes away a tear from her cheek. In desperate need of comfort, she throws herself into his arms. He holds her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: close as she sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all mortal, Bess. We do what we can. He strokes her cheek. She meets his eyes, filled with gratitude. She takes the hand that touches her face and moves it to her lips. She kisses it, still holding his eyes. He draws her back into his arms, and they kiss. Suddenly they're kissing eagerly, greedily, their long pe up passion released at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 A brewer's wagon, pulled by two dray horses and carrying beer barrels, crosses the ancient bridge over the moat an pulls up by the gates. The brewer, a big ugly man called BURTON, looks down at t GUARDS. Beside him, taking care not to draw attention to himself, sits Ramsay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. Another filthy day on God's stinking earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning to you. It's a familiar ritual. The guards search the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 Burton, standing outside, rolls the barrels through a tra door and down a chute into the cellar, where they are caught by the CELLARMAN, and stacked. Another GUARD stand and watches.         B

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last cask! The cellarman takes it, then closes the trap door. The guard watches as the cellarman empties the beer barrels into open vats; leaving the bungs on one side. The barrel are then thrown on a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but beer. Satisfied?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 CLOSE ON the bungs, unnoticed on a side shelf. A FEMALE HAND picks up one of the bungs. Fingers probe. A cavity opens. Inside, tightly folded pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 nnette, Mary Stuart's maid, walks calmly up to the GUARD outside the doors to her mistress's apartments. She nods him, and he unlocks the doors, letting her through.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 nce inside, Annette abandons her calm manner, and hurries through the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame! Madame! Mary Stuart comes to meet her. Annette removes the crumpl papers from her undergarments. Mary crosses herself, take the letter to a lamp, and devours it with eager eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gentlemen are ready. It will be soon now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blessed Mother of God pray for us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring me pen and paper, Annette. They wait on my reply. Hurry, now, hurry! 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon seen through a sextant. A strange figure stands on the flat roof of a riverside house, studying the night sky. He's tall, with a long pointed beard and a skullcap: the famous magus DR JOHN DE A hiss and splash from the night river. He turns to look. Out of the mists and shadows comes the lights of an approaching barge. ON THE ROYAL BARGE - Elizabeth and Walsingham, wrapped against night chill, being rowed up river. Over this, lin led from the next scene:

dialogues.speaker: W
dialogues.text: ell, Dr Dee. Here I am again,                            back to consult the wisdom of                             your charts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 The finest library in England. The greatest array of scientific instruments. Part study, part laboratory, part magician's lair, Dr Dee's house is crammed with the evidence of his wide-ranging curiosity. May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 64

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The magus sits at a table before an astrological chart, while Elizabeth and Walsingham look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alignment of the planets is                    most unusual this year. Mars is                    due to take the ascendant three                    days after the anniversary of                      your birth - your majesty was                      born on September 7th - and I see                  that twelve days before the                        anniversary of your birth -                        He transfers his attention to a different, astronomical chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - there will be a full moon - the                  moon which - He moves back to the astrological chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - governs the fortunes of all princes of the female gender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princes of the female gender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean to say, a prince who is also a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Dr Dee. I am following you. So what does it all mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means the rise of a great empire, majesty. And it means convulsions, also. The fall of an empire. Elizabeth listens, a faraway look in her eyes. She knows nothing of the planets, but she feels it deep within herself: her moment of destiny is near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which empire is to rise, and which is to fall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I can't say. Astrology is, as yet, more an art than a science. May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsingham has been idly examining the scientific instruments. He speaks now as if his question is casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing more, Dr Dee? No more specific calamities that we can guard against?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means, Will I be assassinated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queens are mortal. Dr Dee smiles as he gently contradicts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is mortal. The Queen will never die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Francis? This is a mystery. (to Dee) He has no patience with mysteries. W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I don't know, I can't use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet mysteries have power. Have you not learned that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis. Leave us for a moment. Walsingham leaves. Elizabeth turns to Dr Dee. Now for a short private moment the Queen becomes a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the private life of this prince of the female gender, Dr Dee? What do the stars foretell there? Or is this too a mystery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are matters of state, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do the stars not foretell matters of state?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For such a prediction, I must look in a different chart. May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means her face. He murmurs to himself as he studies he features, reading her character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful... Out of such suffering, to have forged such strength... You will need all your strength in days to come... And love... So much love... But as he looks, he finds something more that disturbs hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you doubt yourself, my                                child... I've not seen fear in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: your face before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I reason to fear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something has weakened you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is danger, yes... Your strength lies in your spirit.                             Nothing else matters. There are

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hard days coming. You must trust the power of your spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is shaken by these words. Dee turns to look out once more at the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm no prophet. I see no more                         than the shadows of ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An art, not a science. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 The royal barge returns down the night river. Elizabeth sits in silence, gazing into the darkness, deep in her ow thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 Raleigh and Bess make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 Elizabeth stands before a long mirror, alone in her dressing chamber, illuminated by lamp light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wears a plain shift. She loosens the ties of her shif and lets it fall to the floor, leaving her naked. She gazes at her own naked body in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: R
dialogues.text: eston sits at the table, writing by candle light. Burton the brewer enters. Reston leaps to his feet, very tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have it? Burton hands him the letter. Reston opens it and reads it at speed. Then he hands it to a man we don't see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? There must be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: clear and valid authority. He gazes at the unseen man, waiting on his verdict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It won't do. Reston nods agreement. He returns to the table and dashes off a letter, muttering as he does so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wait on a direct order. He completes the note and gives it to Burton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more journey, my friend. Then
(fiercely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: consummatum est! It is finished.

dialogues.speaker: 67A
dialogues.text: Bess lies restlessly asleep. Suddenly she gives a start a wakes. She stifles a scream with her hands. On the far si of the room, sitting watching her in silence, is Walsingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! I'm innocent! I've always been a loyal servant of the Queen. I'd never betray the Queen, never -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have, my dear. And you do. We both know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 68

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess knows he means her affair with Raleigh. Now she's to terrified to speak. Walsingham rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep me informed, and all will be well. I don't like surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jump!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dancing master is instructing Bess in the dance calle La Volta, watched by the Queen, her ladies and courtiers. trio of musicians plays a jaunty tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bess) When I push like this, my lady, give a jump into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him throw you round, Bess. You can trust him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dancing master spins Bess round and lifts her up into the air. Her feet fly out as she spins. It's a bold, even risqu dance, and the onlookers laugh to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And round - and round - and round - and down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lowers Bess to the ground. She loves it. As the spinni begins again, Raleigh enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a Volta, Mr Raleigh. The jump. I require all my ladies to learn it. You see how fearless Bess is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh watches Bess dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like your ladies to jump at your command?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes. Do you think that wrong?

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. You're the Queen. You are to be obeyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, Mr Raleigh, there are times when I'm tired of being always in control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mean a word of it. You eat and drink control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you say so? The exercise ends. All clap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess, you must try a dance with Mr Raleigh. He's eager to show us his skill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No skill at all, majesty. I don't know the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's very simple. he goes to Bess to demonstrate, holding her by the waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stand like this, with your hands firmly clasped here - and when she jumps, on the eighth step, you swing her round - once, twice, three times - and you're back to the beginning. What could be simpler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your majesty knows the dance better than I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So come, Mr Raleigh. Take your position. I am to be obeyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As your majesty wishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 70

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh takes his place with Bess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold her tight. I don't want her dropped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to the musicians)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play! The dance begins again. Bess jumps, and Raleigh swings he round and round, finding the knack after an awkward start Elizabeth watches, smiling, nodding to the beat. She can see the faces of the dancers; and so long as she controls the intimacy between them, she's excited by it. Walsingham enters and stands by her side, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave her alone, Walsingham. I want both of them left alone. 69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Stuart is praying, but under cover of her bible, she is writing a secret letter. Sir Amyas Paulet enters, with three men. Mary closes the letter in her bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I a danger to England even when I pray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As always, ma'am, my concern is for your safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pray for my cousin Elizabeth. Do you think she prays for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 Mary's latest letter is now in Reston's hand. Babington a Ramsay sit staring at Reston. This time the Jesuit is pleased. He reads the letter aloud to the unseen man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `If our forces are in readiness, both within and without the realm, then your Queen commands you to set the gentlemen to work.' May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 71 RESTON(cont'd) (with quiet steely                                    satisfaction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we have it. He hands the letter over. For the first time we see who i is: William, now revealed as one of the conspirators. William reads the letter for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding agreement)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the spark that will set                           England ablaze.                                           Reston takes out pistols, and hands one to Ramsay, one to Babington.           R

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been patient long enough.                           Let God's work begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 Walsingham is at work at his desk. A knock on the door. Walsingham does not look up from his papers. William enters, wrapped in a cloak, one hand concealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me. William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still not looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been? We haven't seen you for days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met up with some old friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Paris, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you've come back. He looks up at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know, I can still remember the day you were born? He smiles, but there's sadness in his eyes. May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 72

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was eleven years old. And you, this helpless bundle. I looked at you in your crib, with your little wrinkled face, and I loved you from the first. I vowed then to look after you. I watched you grow up with your head in the clouds, always a dreamer. I couldn't follow you there. And now I've failed you, haven't I? Forgive me if I haven't loved you enough. Clink. Something falls from William's hand to the floor. His face has gone grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you really think I didn't know? On the floor - a dagger. William opens his mouth to answer, but no sound comes out Walsingham raps twice on his desk. The door opens, and Agents 4 and 5 enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it for money? At least tell me you got a good price.

dialogues.speaker: W
dialogues.text: illiam shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What then? What would you murder your own brother for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eternal life. Walsingham stares at him. A great sadness building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eternal life. The bribe no man can refuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 CLOSE ON Elizabeth, surrounded by courtiers and bodyguard as she processes from the Presence Chamber to the Chapel Royal. As before, the way is lined with eager supplicants May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Babington and Ramsay, forcing their way through the crowd to the front line. Elizabeth disappears from view into the Chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen is at her prayers!

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: he chapel doors begin to close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! Ramsay hurls himself forward, shouting -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God for Mary! England's true Queen! The guards run to seize him, opening up a momentary space Babington sprints through it for the closing chapel doors

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 Babington bursts into the chapel, sees a line of ladies kneeling, masking the figure in front of the altar - he pulls out a pistol -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth! Elizabeth turns and rises to confront the assassin's gun. Babington stares at her, hypnotised by her fearlessness. Then he pulls the trigger. Bang! Elizabeth still stares at him. She's unhurt. Babington lets out a cry of anguish, and crumples to the ground. Elizabeth stares on into space, frozen by the moment, magnificent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 Mary paces impatiently in her room, trailed by her little dog. She hears the sound of bells. Joy floods her feature Pounding feet. She turns to see Sir Amyas Paulet hurrying towards her, through a gate in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bring news? May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen has been attacked -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assassin seized -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen unharmed -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unharmed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, ma'am, are under arrest. He has led up to this deliberately, and now stands smilin at her utter confusion. The man who looked like a fool ha been playing his own game all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? What has any of this to do with me? Paulet makes a sign. Burton the brewer comes through the gate: Walsingham's man after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the trouble with intrigue, isn't it? With so many secrets, you can never quite tell who's on who's side, until the game ends. He takes the hollow bung out of one pocket and admires it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My own invention. Theatrical, but effective. My master has every letter you've written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your master?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsingham. Now she knows it's over. She begins to weep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traitors. I'm surrounded by traitors. Who am I to trust?                            May 1 Blue Draft 28 June - p. 75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up her little dog, weeping bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only my little one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 77 Walsingham has a lamp in his hand. He moves slowly along passage, bowed down by a sense of failure. He directs the light of his lamp through cell bars onto a face. The Jesuit. Reston looks back, unafraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready to die, I see, Jesuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have done what I was sent to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was the gun not loaded? Reston doesn't answer. Walsingham gazes at him a moment longer. Then he moves the lamp along. There, shackled and white-faced, sit Babington and Ramsay. Walsingham studies their faces. Walsingham carries his lamp down the passage and shines i into the next cell. Here lies a man in chains, huddled on the floor. He looks up as the light falls on him. William Walsingham looks down on the pitiful sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the Jesuit sent to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To kill the Queen. You know it. You know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told you all I know. Go ahead and kill me. Take what's left of me. I don't care any more. All my life you've had everything and I've had nothing. So finish it. There's a better world waiting for me. We'll all be judged in the end, brother. Even you. Walsingham gazes down on this pitiful show of pride. orchid revision 28 June -p. 76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're no martyr. You weren't even much of a murderer. Go back to France. Back to your dreams. Never let me hear of you again. Walsingham turns away. As he goes we see what he won't sh William: that the hurt of the betrayal is almost more tha he can bear. He goes back up the passage. As he passes Reston, the Jesuit calls out softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send me home.

dialogues.speaker: P
dialogues.text: hilip sits listening intently, staring into space, the Infanta by his side. Don Guerau de Spes is briefing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (They have letters in Mary Stuart's own hand. All England cries out for her death.) Philip nods as he listens. All goes to plan. He turns to the Infanta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (My dearest, how would you like to be Queen of England?) orchid revision 28 June -p. 77

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 Elizabeth sits deep in thought, Bess by her side. Shadows all round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say she's taller than me. Her hair is chestnut in colour.                          Her eyes are hazel. They say                             she's beautiful. But people lie.                         They say I am beautiful.                                 A dismissive shrug. Clearly she does not think herself beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She plotted to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's true. I've read her                            letters. I too was a prisoner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: once. I've feared for my life. I've done terrible things - just                         to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do we all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can be merciful. But she

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: protests her innocence, and that is a lie. Why will she not admit                         she has wronged me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll go on lying til you cut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: out her traitor's heart. Elizabeth stares at her in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to be gentler, Bess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to be quieter, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 Mary Stuart sits before her accusers in the Great Hall of this sombre castle, her new prison. She wears black, but she is proud, composed, and beautiful. She is faced by a commission of lords, appointed to try her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: orchid revision 28 June -p. 77A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you to sit in judgement                         on me? By what authority do you                         condemn a Queen? God alone has                          made me what I am. He is my only                        judge. Raise your law above God's                       law, and what law remains? In                           your vanity and ignorance you set                       loose the monster of misrule. You                       know neither who you are nor what                       you do. But I know who I am. I                          die as I have lived - trusting in                       the mercy of my God - a Queen. 8 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth raging at Walsingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must die? Mary Stuart must die?                         Where is it written? Who dares to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: give orders to the Queen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, this is no time for mercy -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't preach at me, old man. Look at you! You can hardly stand. Go home to your wife. Go home to your bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The law must have its way. orchid revisions 28 june - p.78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The law is for common men, not for princes. Walsingham sees there's no point in persisting. He bows a withdraws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 Raleigh comes hurrying towards the Queen's quarters. Bess sees him approaching and comes out to meet him. They spea low, not wanting the ever-present guards to hear them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God you've come. I've never seen her so distressed. She's been alone in her rooms since morning. She'll see no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has she asked for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But she needs you. I know she does. Raleigh takes Bess's B hand in his, discreetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to her. orchid revisions 28 june - p.79

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 Elizabeth sits alone, deep in thought. Raleigh enters, and comes before her. She doesn't look round, but she knows it's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend. Still she doesn't turn to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Bess bid you come? Have you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: too come to tell me I must murder a Queen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You don't need me to instruct you in your duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My duty? Was it my father's duty to murder my mother? I would be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: loath to die so bloody a death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when were you so afraid? Now she looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am afraid. I am always afraid. Raleigh looks back at her in silence for a long moment. Then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fear your soul will be touched. Royalty is close to immortality. Kill a Queen - and queens are mortal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand me well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We mortals have many weaknesses. We feel too much. Hurt too much. And all too soon, we die. But we do have the chance of love. 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: orchid revisions 28 june - p.79A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we? Do we really? She nods, her eyes still closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe England my life. Don't ask                        for my soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 Mary Stuart at supper, feeding titbits from the table to her little dog. Sir Amyas Paulet enters. Mary sees at once from his face that he brings grave news.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 80

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your face tells me. It's decided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning. At eight. Annette, her maid, bursts into wailing sobs. Mary herself goes very still. She's starting to carry out her final strategy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 The great timbered hall of the castle has been specially prepared for the execution. A stage has been constructed the centre, and around the stage are chairs upon which DIGNITARIES and MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT are already sitting The block dominates the stage. Beside it, the hooded EXECUTIONER with his axe. The DEAN OF PETERBOROUGH in his clerical robes.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: here are more chairs in the body of the hall, occupied by members of the public. They are all waiting for the performance to begin. Mary enters. he people crane their necks to see her. She doesn't disappoint. She is wearing a black velvet gown, her luxurious auburn hair tied in a bunch. Her LADIES, following her in procession, show signs of weeping and distress, but Mary herself glides to the platform with a regal bearing. n her face there is a look that is almost ecstatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 lizabeth, alone. She knows what's happening. She can't rest or be at peace. She tries to sit, then paces, becomi more and more agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 As Mary mounts the stage, the executioner kneels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgiveness, your grace.

dialogues.speaker: N
dialogues.text: may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgive you with all my heart, for now, I hope, you will make an end of all my troubles. She stands, smiling still, and holds out her arms to let her ladies disrobe her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88 ow deeply distressed, Elizabeth suddenly bursts out of th Privy Chamber into the great Presence Chamber, tears welling into her eyes. Bess close behind her. She hardly notices the people around her, until she sees Raleigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want it stopped! 89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's black dress falls to the ground, revealing underneath a petticoat of dark red silk - the colour of martyrdom. There is a collective gasp from the spectators

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 Elizabeth is hysterical, shouting in Raleigh's restrainin arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! It must be stopped!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 Mary kneels, puts her head on the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into your hands, O Lord, I commend my spirit. She stretches out her arms as a signal. The axe comes dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 Elizabeth cries out, as if the axe has fallen on her neck Then she sinks sobbing to the ground, supported by both Raleigh and Bess; and for a moment, the three are united a single embrace.

dialogues.speaker: P
dialogues.text: may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 82

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God save the Queen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 ON THE FACES of the awed spectators. We see, FOREGROUND, the scarlet-clad torso of the executed Mary. A gasp of horror from the spectators. The dead woman's skirts are moving. Out from under her skirts creeps her little dog. The dog looks round, not understanding, and whimpers softly. Annette takes the dog into her arms.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: he sound of cheering crowds outside in the plaza calling out the one Spanish word: `War! War! War!'. hilip enters from the balcony, walking briskly, holding the Infanta by the hand. He comes to a stop before his assembled ministers. His eyes shine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A sweet and Christian lady lies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: martyred, slain by a- Godless- childless- BASTARD! Blood must                           pay for blood! We have just and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: holy cause! I call the legions of Christ to war! Elizabeth! Blood-                         soaked virgin Elizabeth! You will

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pay with your country- your throne- and your life!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 ON WALSINGHAM - As he walks through the palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. In my weakness and my vanity, I have failed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 Walsingham on his knees before Elizabeth, abasing himself in shame. Elizabeth is in control once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How have you failed me? What am I to forgive you for? may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philip of Spain is a God-fearing man. He cannot make war without just cause. He sent the Jesuit to kill a Queen. But not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jesuit's mission was to draw Mary Stuart into the murder plot. He knew I was reading her every letter. He waited until she wrote the words that sealed her guilt. Now Elizabeth gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I ordered her execution. I murdered God's anointed Queen. And now God's most dutiful son makes holy war to punish me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, majesty. Let me go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth hardly hears him any more. She realises the end game is upon her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsingham leaves. Elizabeth never even looks at him. She looking into the distance, preparing herself for what mus now come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 The great Standard of the Armada, bearing the image of th Virgin, is carried into the cathedral. Philip follows, leading a column of Spain's noblest GRANDEES and PRINCES of the church. The ARCHBISHOP sprinkles holy water onto the Standard, an makes the sign of the Cross over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exurge, domine et vindica causam tuam. Amen. Philip kneels to kiss the blessed Standard - which is the thrust aloft again, into the vast spaces of the Cathedral may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 84

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And at once there is a great outpouring of emotion, the congregation applauding, many weeping at the sight. 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 Elizabeth is alone, pacing slowly, reading a book - the Consolation of Philosophy, by Boethius. She reads, pauses looks into the far distance; then reads and walks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Think you that there is any certainty in the affairs of mankind, when you know that one swift hour can destroy the greatest among us?' She turns, and there is Raleigh. She holds up her book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boethius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Consolation of Philosophy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming at this late hour. She closes her book and puts it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at war. Who knows when we'll meet again. If we'll meet again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May the Lord God preserve England's Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same God in whose name Philip wages his holy war. Philip is a righteous man, and righteous men love to destroy. They burn whole worlds to make them pure, and leave behind - ashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll not burn England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may. His Armada is invincible, they say. If London falls, I                              fall. If England is lost, I am                            lost.                                                     may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 85

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never? It's night. My thoughts turn dark. Don't you ever think that one day, perhaps one day soon, you too will die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The closer I come to death, the more I want to live. The hungrier I am for life. His defiant energy breaks Elizabeth's morbid mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. We must live while we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why be afraid of tomorrow? Today's all we have, and all we know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today. Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. They hold each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish - But she can't say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never known a woman like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In some other time, in some other world, could you have loved me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know only one world. In this world, I have loved you. Elizabeth smiles a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there's... something you                       could do for me - something I've not known for a very long time - if you felt so inclined - may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh intuits what she wants. He comes closer as she speaks.              E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something not to be spoken of afterwards - to be forgotten - but just for now - She lifts her head to his. She meets his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kiss? He takes her in his arms, and they kiss. One kiss to hold all that might have been, all that they both know can nev be. When at last they part she turns away from him, head bowe eyes still closed, holding on to the sweet moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 CLOSE IMAGES as the Armada standard is carried in procession to the flagship, and hoisted into position on the ship's towering prow. Cannons fire a booming salute. As the standard billows in the breeze, beyond it we see t forest of masts that make up the great Armada. 101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The palace is galvanised by the invasion threat. Armed me go by at the double, passing servants hauling out trolley bearing valuables, as the court prepares for the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh and Howard stride fast across the Guard Chamber, the first of the sequence of great rooms. They are deep i war talk. Bess appears ahead, and beckons him to a secluded corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess, I've been ordered to my ship - Bess stops his mouth with one finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be quick. I have something to tell you. But I ask for nothing. Is that understood? Your life is your own. Nothing will change. may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Bess? Two court officials hurry by. Bess lowers her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm - Her hand touches her waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one knows. My plans are made. I shall ask the Queen for permission to leave court. I shall live quietly in the country with - with my child. The Queen must know nothing. Raleigh stares at her, stunned. More people are passing. This is no place for R displays of strong feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To my mother's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a ward of the Queen. I can't court a man without her permission. I can't marry without her permission. As for having a child - Another official passes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When were you planning to leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as I'm allowed. Raleigh finds himself caught in an impossible situation. His internal struggle shows itself in the twists and jerk of his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I not to see you again? What's to become of the child? Bess -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 88

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush! We've no choice. You know it as well as I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is nothing's as it should be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please listen. You once said to me, `Whatever I have to give, ask and it's yours.' Do you remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask that you forget me. Go to your ship. Do your duty. Forget me.

dialogues.speaker: R
dialogues.text: aleigh gazes at her, deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Bess... The Queen's ladies come hurrying by. Margaret calls to Be as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess! We're summoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming. (to Raleigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. She runs after the ladies. Raleigh walks slowly after them down the hall. On his fac a new look forms. He knows now what he's going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 An empty horizon. Then, on the very line of the horizon, the ghost of a movement. Far away, too small to make out, something is coming. 1 may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104 Elizabeth starts up in bed, calls out in sudden fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air! I must have air! Her servants hurry in, and open the window. Elizabeth goes to the open window and breathes in deeply. She looks up at the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With this ring I thee wed. With my body I thee worship... 05

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh and Bess are being married in secret by a PRIEST. The only witness is Bess's fellow maid of honour Margaret Raleigh makes his vow tenderly and lovingly, his eyes on Bess throughout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and with all my worldly goods H         I thee endow. e places the ring on her left thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of the father - He moves the ring to her forefinger -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And of the Son - To her index finger -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And of the Holy Spirit. And finally onto her ring finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 106 A room in which a map of Europe is inlaid in the floor. A table strewn with maps stands in the centre. Elizabeth is imperious, back in control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey Revisions 22 June -p.90

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Spanish Armada is at sea carrying an army of ten thousand men. (indicating on the map)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duke of Parma has fifteen thousand men on the French coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They plan to cross the Channel in barges, under the protection of the Spanish fleet, and sail up the Thames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they don't yet have enough barges at Calais. We have a little time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our forces defend the Thames

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: entrance at Tilbury. How many men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have three, possibly four thousand, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the Spanish fleet reaches Calais in strength, the combined armies will be beyond our power to resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore, the Spanish fleet must not reach Calais.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, this vast Armada will surely smash through our naval defences. We must be prepared for the worst.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: lizabeth walks briskly through the great public rooms bac to her quarters, with Walsingham by her side and her entourage following behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know about the numbers of the Dutch barges, majesty? I don't recall supplying you with that information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may observe, Walsingham, that I don't see my way with only one eye. Nor do I hop along on only one leg. Why then would I rely on only one source of information? She sweeps into her quarters. Her ladies, waiting there, jump up in haste. She scans them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Bess? Her eyes coem to rest on Margaret. She sees that Margaret knows something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108 We are on the very tip of England. A watch-tower has been built, and next to it a large beac of wood. A YOUNG MAN is minding the watch. He stares out to sea, catching sight of something. Over t rim of the world has appeared the long line of the Spanis fleet, like a floating wall, black and menacing.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: e runs down the steps from the tower. He lights a bundle of sticks and thrusts them again and again into the beaco The beacon catches fire. As the flames rise into the sky, so a second beacon erupts into flame on the next headland And then a third on the next, a fourth on the next, a fifth, disappearing around the coastline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 Doors burst open and Elizabeth comes storming out, barely containing a powerful rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess! Bess Throckmorton! Bess comes running from the far end. May 1 Blue Draft -p.92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, my lady!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me! Is it true? Are you                          married? Are you with child? Are                      you WITH CHILD?                                       Bess stands before her with her head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my lady.                                         Elizabeth falls on her with uncontrolled rage, striking o at her, beating her about the head, shrieking out the wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: that so inflame and wound her. Bess takes the blows in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You traitress! You dare to have                       secrets from me! I am your Queen!                     You ask my permission before you rut - before you marry - before you breed! My bitches wear my collars! Do you hear me? How dare you be with child! Walsingham comes hobbling up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, please! Dignity - mercy - But Elizabeth is too far gone. She turns on him, eyes blazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is no time for mercy! That's what you said to me. I don't forget. But you showed mercy, Walsingham! Go to your traitor brother, and leave me to my business!

dialogues.speaker: W
dialogues.text: alsingham turns white. Elizabeth is back berating Bess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it his child? Tell me! Say it! Is the child his? Tell me! Say it! Is it his? Bess responds to the Queen's hysteria with dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my lady. It is - my husband's child. Her gaze reaches beyond the Queen. Elizabeth turns.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft -p.93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raleigh has come up to them unnoticed. He has seen and heard all. He speaks to Elizabeth quietly, sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the Queen I love and serve. Elizabeth stares at him. He meets her eyes. His gaze is s unflinching that slowly the madness drains out of her. Wh she speaks next, she is her proud self again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gentleman has seduced a lady                         under my care. This lady has                              married without my consent. These are offences punishable by law. (to Walsingham)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrest him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 111 rom way up high we see beacon after warning beacon bursting into flame, the light from them describing the contours of England. As they rush on, they suddenly divide, some continuing along the coast, others racing inland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr Dee watches as Elizabeth prowls his cluttered rooms, releasing the tension that has swelled to bursting point within her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fall of an empire, you told me. Did you mean the English empire? Because by God, England will not fall while I am Queen! If that's your prophecy, sir, prophesy again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to tell your majesty only what your majesty chooses to hear?

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: May 1 Blue Draft -p.94

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not be a toy of the fates! Have I not faced an assassin's bullet and lived? She turns to Dr Dee and sees his quizzical gaze on her, a she lets her rage pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me there's no certainty. The shadows of ghosts, you said. Any outcome is possible. Give me hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forces that shape the world are greater than all of us, majesty. How can I promise you that they'll conspire in your favour, even though you are the Queen? But this much I know. When the storm breaks, each man acts in accordance with his own nature. Some are dumb with terror. Some flee. Some hide. And some spread their wings like eagles and soar on the wind. Elizabeth understands. She draws herself up, finding now the self-belief she needs for the battle to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a wise man, Dr Dee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, madam, are a very great lady.

dialogues.speaker: 112B
dialogues.text: lizabeth stares out of the window, watches as the last beacon is kindled not far away, and bursts into flame. Behind her stand her ministers: Hatton, Howard, and Walsingham.

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: he turns to face the others. All littleness has dropped away. She sees only her nation's hour of destiny, and her own duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lords, I can offer you no                              words of comfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.95 ELIZABETH(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this Armada succeeds there                            will be no more freedom in our land, and England will be no more. We cannot be defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 The unending line of Spanish ships advances over the wate Still far away, but scary in power and reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What news? Is the fleet at sea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. May God preserve them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 114 Raleigh lies awake and fully dressed on the bed in his prison room. The room is furnished for a gentleman, but t walls are thick and the windows barred. The door opens, and a servant brings in a tray of food. Raleigh sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Spanish are off Portland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the fleet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still at Plymouth, joined by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drake and all the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All but me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 115 The white cliffs of England, seen from the Channel. INTO FRAME sweeps a SPANISH ENSIGN, streaming from a mast And another, and another. Mast after mast, straining sail shivering ropes, and the FLAGS of the enemy - flying from the top-gallants of a hundred ships - so near to England now that they seem to have been planted already on England's white cliffs. DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.95A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 The Queen, Sir Christopher Hatton, Walsingham and her entourage, all now heavily armed, enter the great vaulted nave of St Paul's. As they make their way towards the altar, Elizabeth issues commands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bells are to ring in every church in the land. Hatton bows to show he has received the order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Labourers are to leave the fields and take up arms. The harvest must wait. Hatton bows and leaves. Elizabeth continues up the nave, now followed only by Walsingham. She turns to him with another order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Release all prisoners. England is their country too. She moves forward again. Walsingham follows, waiting, knowing there's more. Elizabeth turns to him one last tim

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Release Raleigh. He is forgiven... As I too pray to be forgiven... Walsingham leaves. Elizabeth goes forward to stand before the altar alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me. All of you. The remainder of her entourage bow and withdraw. Elizabet goes on down the nave to the altar, and there, at the foo of the steps, sinks to her knees. She does not bow her head. ON ELIZABETH - Alone in the great space, staring at her G

dialogues.speaker: P
dialogues.text: as at an equal. AN UP to the blazing coloured light of the stained glass window - 117

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN from high windows to see monks praying for the succe of the Armada. Their chant has a driving war-like rhythm, that carries over the following scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 SPEED TRACK down a palace corridor, urged on by the beat the chant, into Philip's cell. TRACK IN to the flame of a single candle: its bright hear seems to be the source of the pounding chant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 The chant powers on. SHIPS' BOWS slice the water, racing towards us. DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.97

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 ON PHILIP as the chant drives on, murmuring his own praye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tu es Deus qui facis mirabilia solus. Notam fecisti in gentibus virtutem tuam...

dialogues.speaker: 120A
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON RALEIGH - A Royal Official has just handed him a letter. He reads it and then looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the Queen I will join my

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 121 The chant continues - TRACKING THROUGH English troops to the Queen's tent -

dialogues.speaker: EXT PLYMOUTH HARBOUR
dialogues.text: The English fleet sets sail and leaves Plymouth harbour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 The Queen's advisers mill round Elizabeth. Walsingham is seated in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are our ships at sea? Has the fleet left Plymouth? That can't be so hard to know. ADMIRAL WINTER enters, out of breath, clutching the lates reports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enemy has been engaged, majesty. He reads as he speaks. The news is not so good after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brave action. Two ships lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With what gain? DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.97A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enemy continues to advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123 FOREGROUND - Floating wreckage, and the bodies of English sailors. Beyond, the long line of the Spanish fleet, advancing, firing. The Spanish ships are monsters, much taller than the English ships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double Pink revision 18 July- p.98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 124 Lord Howard bent over a mass of charts with his commander round him: HAWKINS, DRAKE, FROBISHER and Raleigh. The boo of Spanish cannon shakes the air. Flashes of fire light t faces of the English officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must attack! What choice do we have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're decisively outgunned, Drake. We are losing too many

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ships. We must defend the coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying the chart of the Armada's progress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There has to be a way of getting                         inside this crescent formation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our ships may be smaller but

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: they're nimbler. We should use the strengths we've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, we're out-gunned. Do you want to lose the whole fleet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break their formation and we have

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't get near them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 125 Elizabeth among her advisers. An air of mounting panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Spanish are barely a day away, majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: t would be wise to withdraw to safer ground. Grey Revision 22 June - p.99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you to appreciate the gravity of the situation, majesty. There is very little time. Elizabeth turns on him, calm and defiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we must act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 126 A low distant beat as we TRACK THROUGH the English camp. The soldiers are a citizen army, no hardened professional We pass a troop busy sharpening their pikes; an older soldier in quiet prayer; a band sharing drinks; a youth rubbing down a horse. Now they hear the distant beat approaching. One by one th look up, surprised, uncertain. Now they hear it loud and clear: the beat of an army on t march. CLOSE ON tramping feet. An advancing force. Horses' hoove beating the ground.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: N THE SOLDIERS' FACES - Staring, half afraid, half expectant - then filled with a surge of sudden hope - SOLDIERS' POV - English flags rising over the low brow of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 127 In the midst of the advancing array of banners and flags, riding a white horse, dressed in silver armour, holding a silver staff - Elizabeth - transformed into a goddess of war. The thousands of gaping soldiers sink awe-struck to their knees. ON ELIZABETH as she surveys her rag-tag army. The army le out a cheer. The Queen cries out to ore) army, her voice echoing in th (m her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: chill air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My loving people! We see the sails of the enemy approaching. We hear the Spanish guns over the water.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: Goldenrod revision 1 June - p.100 ELIZABETH(cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon now we will meet them face                           to face. In that encounter,                               England lives, or England dies. I                         am resolved in the midst and heat                         of the battle to live or die                              amongst you all!                                          A cheer from the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
